content.description:
This is the farthest left line that climbs the steepest part of the wall. It is probably the steepest 5.12 in the Summit County area. Climb up easy moves to a overhanging, small, white dihedral. Power through the dynamic crux to a shake at 3/4 height, then climb up a pumpy finish to the anchors. This shares anchors with

Thunder Buffalo

.
content.protection: 5 draws fixed anchors. You may want to put up some project draws, because it's hard to clean.
content.location:
It is farthest left line that is very steep. Quincy's memorial plaque is up and slightly left of the base. Belay from the platform under

Thunder Buffalo

.

content.description:
This route is more or less a bolted boulder problem. Like

POU

, if it were longer it would get more stars. 2 boulder problems separated by a decent shake comprise this line. The first one hits you right as you pull on the start holds, so make sure you are warmed up.
content.protection: 4 bolts plus anchors. You can't see the last bolt from the ground. As of now, there are fixed draws on the first 3 bolts, bring a draw for the last bolt.
content.location: This is the first route you see when you get to the crag where the trail meets the wall. It is the rightmost route on the crag.

content.description:
Thunder Buffalo is a worthy tick for the 5.11 climber or the perfect warm-up for the harder lines here. This route is game on from the start (stickclip the first, if not second, bolt). It is technical, thoughtful, and somewhat beta specific throughout. There are a couple rests on this climb if you look for them. Save some gas for the finishing sequence guarding the chains.

There is a (currently) closed project that branches off the third bolt of this line to the right and finishes at its own set of anchors above the blank panel.
content.protection:
6 bolts to fixed anchors with lowering biners. It shares anchors with

WTRF

.
content.location:
This route is on the far left side of the wall, just right of

When the Rain Falls

.

content.description:
This line is currently a project in the .13 range. It branches right off of the 3 bolt of

Thunder Buffalo

for an additional 4 bolts. There used to be a piece of white tape on the first bolt where it branches.

A hold broke making this thing hard, probably unpleasant 13+. It is a first ascent to whomever can climb it.
content.location:
It branches right off of

Thunder Buffalo

at the 3rd bolt.

content.description: This is the crag warm-up. This route would get more stars if only it were longer. It is still a very fun and worthy line. Some easy climbing on big holds leads to a fun, tricky sequence in the middle and then to a good rest. Clip the last bolt, and figure out your beta for the lip/mantel to the chains.
content.location: It is more or less in the middle of the crag, just right of a slab that bisects the wall. Look for the start jug with a cute little tree growing out of it.

content.description:
This is the newest route on the wall.

Thus far, this is the only route on the Upstairs Slab.

Start out with a short scramble up to the base of the route.

Good crimps and some vertical features in the rock help you move up and slightly left as you climb.

The route has not seen much traffic, so it is a bit gritty yet. It is always a good idea for your belayer to have a helmet.
content.location: This route is on a wall called the Upstairs above the main Cache Wall. From Cache, follow the fixed line around the base, and scramble up the trail to the base of the obvious, slab wall. It climbs the very middle of the wall and is currently the only route there.
